messages.text:
Don't worry about it. It's one of the many unwritten style rules that
have evolved over time.

We have normally considered it okay to have articles ("a", "an",
"the") before the documented noun when it makes sense. Here you have
made a couple of sentences feel a bit more stilted.

Hello golang-dev@googlegroups.com,

I'd like you to review this change to
https://dvyukov@google.com@code.google.com/p/go/

*** Submitted as e7e49c318134 ***

runtime/pprof: fix comments

R=golang-dev, iant
CC=golang-dev
http://codereview.appspot.com/6460082

On Wed, Aug 15, 2012 at 3:57 AM, David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org> wrote:

> On 15 Aug 2012 02:29, "Dmitry Vyukov" <dvyukov@google.com> wrote:
>
> > I thought it's a convention to have exactly the function/type name as
> the first word... Do I need to revert?
>
> The convention is to use the noun first, with an optional article before
> it.
>
> I wouldn't bother reverting. Just don't make similar changes in the future.
>

Got it. Sorry.

I thought it's a convention to have exactly the function/type name as the
first word... Do I need to revert?



On Tue, Aug 14, 2012 at 4:26 AM, David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org> wrote:

> We have normally considered it okay to have articles ("a", "an",
> "the") before the documented noun when it makes sense. Here you have
> made a couple of sentences feel a bit more stilted.
>

On 15 Aug 2012 02:29, "Dmitry Vyukov" <dvyukov@google.com> wrote:

> I thought it's a convention to have exactly the function/type name as the
first word... Do I need to revert?

The convention is to use the noun first, with an optional article before it.

I wouldn't bother reverting. Just don't make similar changes in the future.

On Wed, Aug 15, 2012 at 4:16 PM, David Symonds <dsymonds@golang.org> wrote:

> Don't worry about it. It's one of the many unwritten style rules that
> have evolved over time.
>
i think we really need to write them down in the effective Go article.

FWIW, the convention is to let the rules of English take priority.
Whether it makes sense to have an article depends on English usage,
not a Go rule.

There are two ways to document a type. One is to explain the type
itself. Another is to explain what a single instance of the type
represents. In the former case the sentence should typically begin
with the type name, but in the latter it should typically begin with
an article. Again, this isn't Go-specific, just English usage. "Dog is
a word. A dog is an animal."

I have sent out a CL to undo the article changes here.

Russ

Thanks!


On Fri, Aug 31, 2012 at 6:11 PM, Russ Cox <rsc@golang.org> wrote:

> FWIW, the convention is to let the rules of English take priority.
> Whether it makes sense to have an article depends on English usage,
> not a Go rule.
>
> There are two ways to document a type. One is to explain the type
> itself. Another is to explain what a single instance of the type
> represents. In the former case the sentence should typically begin
> with the type name, but in the latter it should typically begin with
> an article. Again, this isn't Go-specific, just English usage. "Dog is
> a word. A dog is an animal."
>
> I have sent out a CL to undo the article changes here.
>
> Russ
>
